original_data.question: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches during the past 2 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. A metyrapone stimulation test is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following changes in laboratory findings are most likely to have been observed in this patient following the administration of the drug?

model_response:
The metyrapone stimulation test is used to assess hypothalamic-pituitary function. Metyrapone inhibits 11-b-hydroxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol. In patients with Cushing's syndrome, the increase in ACTH due to loss of feedback inhibition results in an increase in 11-deoxycortisol. Following administration of metyrapone, 11-deoxycortisol levels decrease, and cortisol levels increase because the block in the synthesis of cortisol at the 11-deoxycortisol step allows corticosterone to be converted to cortisol. Urinary 17-hydroxycorticosteroids are increased in patients with Cushing's syndrome because of the increased glucocorticoid production.

Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

A dietary supplement containing all or most of the vitamins that may not be readily available in the diet. Vitamins may be classified according to their solubility either in lipids (vitamins A, D, E, K, F) or in water (vitamins C, B-complex). Present in minute amounts in various foods, vitamins are essential to maintaining normal metabolism and biochemical functions. (NCI04)
An inhibitor of the enzyme STEROID 11-BETA-MONOOXYGENASE. It is used as a test of the feedback hypothalamic-pituitary mechanism in the diagnosis of CUSHING SYNDROME.
The result of a laboratory, radiologic, or other clinical test performed to determine the presence, absence, or degree of a condition.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.

Conditions in which the production of adrenal CORTICOSTEROIDS falls below the requirement of the body. Adrenal insufficiency can be caused by defects in the ADRENAL GLANDS, the PITUITARY GLAND, or the HYPOTHALAMUS.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
The outcome of a laboratory test.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
